adjective.description: Additional to what is required for ordinary use.
examples: few people had spare cash for inessentials
her clothes are smart and spare in style

noun.description: An item kept in case another item of the same type is lost, broken, or worn out.
(in tenpin bowling) an act of knocking down all the pins with two consecutive rolls of the ball.

verb.description: Give (something of which one has enough) to (someone); afford to give to.
examples: she asked if I could spare her a dollar or two

verb.description: Refrain from killing, injuring, or distressing.
examples: there was no way the men would spare her
but some will spend, and some will spare

phrases: he'd go spare if he lost the money
The garden magpies are going spare just now, burying seeds and nuts in random places.
Nine, Ten, and the ABC would go spare at that.
Your mother actually sent me up, she's going spare downstairs.
I was shocked to see that someone had been digging badgers out - I went spare and my wife had to calm me down.
origin: Old English sp√¶r not plentiful, meager, sparian refrain from injuring, refrain from using, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German sparen to spare.
